geekdawson 160573034703 "2017-05-12 03:43:27 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/160573034703/heres-some-stupid-adult-advice-sometimes-you "Here’s some stupid adult advice:Sometimes you should sit down and take stock of your life and what you’re doing. The world is really big and there will be a lot of paths and opportunities to pursue and seize. It will feel like you want to do everything. But the older you get
column2: the more you’re going to find that it’s easy to let the noise drown out the things you MOST want. Making a determination about what is most important to you and how you build it/pursue it is so
column4: you guys. Every once in a while you have to sit down and spend some time really thinking about where you’re at
column6: and what will most fulfill you in life. And then pursue those things that will get you where you want to go and most fulfill you
column7: hopefully in equal measure (but of course
column8: sometimes you’re going to compromise). An abundance of opportunity is spectacular
column9: but a life filled with the things you want most
column10: that you get excited to wake up and pursue….that’s the best feeling in the world. Stop and take stock. Make your life the thing you most want it to be
column11: or make a plan to get it there at least. Stay strong. Stay soft." True text

column1: geekdawson 157839181333 "2017-02-28 23:44:07 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/157839181333/say-their-names-in-memory-of-ciara-mcelveen-and "gaywrites: In the last few days we’ve learned that two more Black transgender women have been murdered: Ciara McElveen (pictured above) and Chyna Doll Dupree. Both women were from New Orleans
column2: and their deaths were reported only two days apart. So far
column3: six transgender people have been killed in 2017. It’s not even March.   In a statement
column5: an LGBTQ youth advocacy organization based in New Orleans
column6: said it will be creating space for friends and family to grieve and celebrate the lives of McElveen and Dupree. “While the numbers are staggering and many in our communities are still in shock
column7: some BreakOUT! members say that they refuse to be afraid and that they won’t be silent
column8: ” the organization said in a statement to Mic. “But we have so much other work to do in our communities — we need jobs
column10: education and access to safe spaces — and yet we continue to have to simply fight for our lives.“   Devastating. Rest in peace and power. " False link

column1: geekdawson 156657705658 "2017-02-01 05:00:36 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/156657705658/rachel-bloom-wrote-a-song-for-the-flash "cwsupergirlgifs: Crazy Ex-Girlfriend star Rachel Bloom has co-written a song for The CW’s upcoming musical crossover between The Flash and Supergirl
column2: BuzzFeed News can exclusively reveal! “As soon as I heard that they were doing a musical crossover
column3: I e-mailed Mark Pedowitz who connected me to Greg and Andrew. I immediately offered them my services
column4: ” Bloom told BuzzFeed News in a statement. “As soon as they picked one of my song ideas
column5: I hopped on the phone with my old Robot Chicken boss Tom Root and we brainstormed and
column7: I wrote up the song ‘Superfriends.’ I am so excited to contribute more to the upward trend that is musicals in television and film. Music can be one of the most amazing and efficient forms of storytelling and character development. Also
column8: it was really fun to write a comedy song for two superheroes.” “Superfriends” will be performed by Grant Gustin and Melissa Benoist in “Duet
column9: ” The Flash portion of the two-episode crossover
column10: airing March 21 (the musical action kicks off at the end of Supergirl’s March 20 episode). Jesse L. Martin
column14: and John Barrowman will also be singing in the episode
column15: which guest stars Glee alum Darren Criss as Music Meister
column16: a.k.a. the musical’s big bad. " False link

column1: geekdawson 155094548938 "2016-12-29 01:19:08 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/155094548938/comic-book-publisher-puts-the-call-out-for "laurellynnleake:  queercomicsconnection:  moonjellybeans: If anyone on my friends list is interested??? :D Stacked Deck Press is looking for more artists to join in their upcoming anthology We’re Still Here
column2: a new anthology the company hopes will showcase a diverse roster of trans illustrators.   “We’re hoping to include a whole bunch of contributions by  as-yet-unknown trans cartoonists
column3: as well as to promote wider awareness  of those already working at a relatively high professional level
column5: who is co-editing the project with trans creator Tara  Avery
column6: told Newsarama. “I think this is a significant project for indie comics
column7: and for comics in general.” A number of artists have already been confirmed for We’re Still Here
column12: and Christine Smith (Eve’s Apple) [and Melanie Gillman (As The Crow Flies) and Annie Mok (Swim Through Fire)].  From their submissions page:   Our goal is to present work 100 percent conceived and executed by trans  artists
column15: and approaches trans  people are taking to comics work today. And if you’re a trans person who  makes comics (or would like to)
column16: we’re definitely interested in seeing  what you’ve got to offer.  A few important specs for submission: SDP is looking for 1-8 page stories that have not been published anywhere else (it’s not clear whether they count online and/or self publishing)
column17: open to any genre/topic.  Payment starts at $20 per page
column19: but has pay raises built into an upcoming Kickstarter.  Pages are 6″x7″
column22: and “Trans creators of color to the front of the line.”  What you need to submit toe  ditor@stackeddeckpress.com by January 9
column23: 2017:  A short pitch for your idea OR a full script How many pages you’d need Roughs/thumbnails for at least 1-2 pages Samples of your finished art in the style you’d be using  Hey comics friends

column1: geekdawson 152576892688 "2016-11-01 00:43:52 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/152576892688/the-luke-cage-syllabus-a-breakdown-of-all-the "notyourhomeboy:  lagonegirl:  #LukeCageSyllabus  Acres of Skin: Human Experiments at Holmesburg Prison by Allen M. Hornblum Luke Cage’s beginnings as a scientific experiment are not too far from the truth
column2: especially since his power resides in his skin. Acres of Skin discusses the history of medical experiments on Black prisoners that helped make skin grafts possible. A more recent book that chronicles medical experiments on Black people throughout America’s history is Harriet A. Washington’s Medical Apartheid: The Dark History of Medical Experimentation on Black Americans from Colonial Times to the Present.  Cutting Along the Color Line: Black Barbers and Barber Shops in America by Quincy T. Mills. The history of Black barber shops as a gathering place is not surprising
column3: and when people congregate and share ideas in Pop’s Barber Shop or metaphorically refer to his spot as “Switzerland
column4: ” Mills’ book offers some insight into why barber shops are about more than cutting hair.  Can’t Stop
column5: Won’t Stop by Jeff Chang If you don’t get the hip hop references
column6: Jeff Chang’s survey history of hip hop’s beginnings will probably help
column7: but it also talks about the concept of “benign neglect” and how public policy
column9: and social conditions helped create hip hop. One of the key players in that scenario is Robert Moses. For more on him
column10: there’s Robert A. Caro’s The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York.  Free Stylin’: How Hip Hop Changed the Fashion Industry by Elena Romero At this point
column11: hip hop has left its mark on fashion. The documentary Fresh Dressed shows how hip hop artists invented their own fashions out of necessity and have become trendsetters in elite circles. Free Stylin’ is the scholarly take on how hip hop changed fashion.  Fist Stick Knife Gun: A Personal History of Violence by Geoffrey Canada In one scene
column12: Cottonmouth Stokes mocks his cousin Mariah for wanting to go “the Geoffrey Canada route.” Canada is best known for his book Fist Stick Knife Gun and founding Harlem Children’s Zone. Another book about Canada and his work is Whatever It Takes: Geoffrey Canada’s Quest to Change Harlem and America by Paul Tough.  Where’s Waldo? by Martin Handford Since Misty Knight visualizes the logistics of every crime scene through photographs
column13: she explains how she was always the fastest at finding Waldo as a kid. This is the only children’s book mentioned.  Playing the Numbers: Gambling in Harlem between the Wars by Shane White Wealth-building in Harlem was also part of an underground economy that allowed some Black business owners to support local artists
column19: and racketeering in movies likeHoodlum or The Cotton Club. There are other history books that
column22: a woman very much like Mama Mabel in Luke Cage. Another book worth reading next to this one could be Harlem: The Unmaking of a Ghetto by Camilo José Vergara. Diamondback
column24: touts The 48 Laws of Power and carries around a heavily annotated edition of the Bible that his mother gave him.  Negroes and The Gun: The Black Tradition of Arms by Nicholas Johnson Another nod to Diamondback is when he insists to Mariah Dillard that the history of guns in America is built on creating fear towards Black people after Reconstruction
column25: when the Ku Klux Klan rose to prominence and Jim Crow began to thrive. Johnson’s book not only relates to Diamondback’s point
column26: but also reveals the tension between self-defense
column28: and the nonviolent practices of the Civil Rights era. In the last episode
column29: Luke is holding a copy of The Heat’s On by Chester Himes. Luke also mentions Michael Connelly
column30: author of the 21 existing Harry Bosch novels. There so many allusions and references sprinkled through this thirteen hours of television. Add any I may have missed
column31: or that you think are required reading
column32: in the comments or on Twitter with the #LukeCageSyllabus tag
column33: so we can find it.  I have to read these. " False link

column1: geekdawson 150000350333 "2016-09-05 22:13:49 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/150000350333/life-in-the-native-american-oil-protest-camps "tlatollotl:  An Indian reservation in North Dakota is the site of the largest gathering of Native Americans in more than 100 years. Indigenous people from across the US are living in camps on the Standing Rock reservation as they protest the construction of a new oil pipeline. As a result
column2: a new community has emerged. The BBC’s Charlie Northcott went to North Dakota to meet the protesters and discover what goes on in camp.     Peter Francis
column4: has spent a week hauling iron pots between a holding tank and an open fire to maintain a continuous flow of boiling water for tea and cooking. He is staying in the Red Warrior Camp
column5: one of two enormous gatherings of Native American people near the Cannonball River
column6: in the US state of North Dakota. He stands
column8: in protest against an oil pipeline. “This is about water
column10: referring to the protest. “Water is the life of our people. Without it
column11: we cannot exist.”     The Red Warrior Camp is situated in a remote corner of the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation
column12: near the confluence of the Missouri and Cannonball rivers. The multi-billion dollar oil pipeline the campers are opposing is slated to pass beneath the Missouri
column13: just north of Standing Rock. The protesters say the pipeline will despoil a number of sacred sites in the area
column14: including the flooded forest pictured here
column15: which used to be a burial ground. The bleached trees are said to be the skeletons of Lakota Dakota spirits.     Life in the camps is often quiet. Whole families have based themselves there
column16: having driven from as far afield as Maine and Arizona - hundreds of miles across America. Hours are spent around camp fires
column17: sharing stories and food. Traditional Native American staples are on the menu
column21: which is eaten sweet and savoury.   A cohort of young men patrol the Red Warrior Camp calling themselves “spirit riders.” They spend most of their time running errands and delivering messages. They are excellent riders
column24: occasionally galloping in the nearby floodplain. The Sioux people have a long history of horsemanship
column25: defeating the US army repeatedly in pitched horse battles in the 1800s - most famously at the Battle of Little Bighorn
column26: where the invading General Custer was killed.   Hawste Wakiyan Wicasa believes the Native American standoff with Dakota Access is the last Great Indian War. “This is the first time the seven bands of the Sioux have come together since Little Bighorn
column29: only prayers.” Mr Wicasa says he prays every morning and every night in the sweat lodge pictured behind him. “We are here for what our ancestors fought and died for. We have endured 250 years of betrayal by the white man.”     The company behind the oil pipeline
column31: says it will create thousands of jobs and generate over $40m (£30.5m) in tax revenue for the state of North Dakota. Seven counties will be traversed in total
column32: in addition to the states of Iowa
column33: Illinois and South Dakota. The pipeline will follow the line of the power cables visible in the backdrop of this picture
column34: as seen from the outer edge of the Red Warrior Camp.     Amihan
column36: pictured here with a friend she made in the Sacred Stone Camp
column37: drove from Ohio to participate in the protest. Many protesters have been living in the camps for weeks
column38: but some are just passing through. Standing Rock has seen hundreds of young indigenous people and activists visit
column39: eager to take part in the historic gathering. Over 80 different tribes have a presence in the area.     On most days
column40: demonstrations take place along the road leading to the Dakota Access pipeline construction site. Participants wave flags representing different tribal nations. In some cases
column41: they obstruct trucks and diggers approaching the pipeline. Over 20 Native American protesters have been arrested in the month of August
column42: including the chairman of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe
column45: is from the Standing Rock Reservation. He has been protesting against the pipeline since April
column46: and worries the camps are becoming overcrowded and that local supplies are overstretched. “We know this place can’t handle many more people
column48: standing in the Sacred Stone Camp. “Resources are stretched. Our community does not have a lot of money.”     Clyde Bellecourt is one of the founders of the American Indian Movement
column49: a significant civil rights group in the 1960s and 70s. In all his days fighting for Native American rights
column50: he says he has never seen anything like the camps. “I am 80 years old
column52: I’ve been shot. This is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen. This is what I fought for.”     At the centre of the Red Warrior Camp is a microphone
column54: a blazing fire. Anyone can stand up and speak or sing. Here
column56: an organiser for the Indigenous Environmental Network
column57: delivers a speech about camp logistics. “The porta potties [toilets] are the most expensive things here
column59: to a chorus of laughter. “Please do your stuff neatly.”     For children
column60: the protest camps are a playground of excitement. Dogs run wild
column61: horses are available to be ridden. The two camps are close to the river
column62: which offers relief in the humidity of summer.     Govinda Dalton is one of an older generation of environmental activists living in the camp. He runs Spirit Resistance Radio 87.9 out of his white van. Social media use by young Native Americans has been the driving force behind the growth of the protest
column64: #NoDakotaAccess and #nodapl. Instagram and Facebook have been the most popular mediums
column65: but Twitter is also being used. “This is what it’s about man
column67: many of them private and closed to outsiders
column68: are part of the everyday life of the camp. Each tribe brings its own set of customs
column69: but many find common ground with songs
column70: chanting and pipe-smoking rituals. Here Chloe Piepho says a prayer to Mni Wiconi
column72: in the Lakota Sioux language.     Johnelle
column74: is always in a rush. She is the emergency response coordinator for the Standing Rock Sioux tribe. She runs a logistics team
column76: medical and media officers. Looking out for the lives of thousands of visitors has been a challenge
column77: but she relishes it. “If we find out there is something people need
column81: we will find it for them.”     The human rights organisation Amnesty International
column82: pictured here interviewing Ladonna Brave Bull
column83: is investigating whether Native American liberties have been infringed. Local law enforcement have blocked a major road to and from the Red Warrior Camp
column84: citing the interest of public safety. Residents of the camp say the blockage prevents them from picking up basic supplies from their nearest city
column86: cleaning and cooking are all handled by volunteers in the two protest camps. Some of have been told to keep track of the media
column87: who are scantly trusted. “We don’t bother them
column89: a 17-year-old volunteer on the security team. “But it’s good to keep watch
column90: to see who is here.”     On 9 September
column91: a major decision will be made regarding the Red Warrior Camp and its protesters. A judicial court will decide whether the Dakota Access pipeline should proceed
column92: or be halted for further environmental and archaeological assessments. “This is the biggest gathering of its kind in history
column94: on the camps. “We will stand our ground if we have to.“ " False link

column1: geekdawson 146723556218 "2016-06-30 22:33:55 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/146723556218/the-kids-are-all-rightbut-why-pacific-standard "kenyatta: According to an examination by Scientific American (and a separate 2011 review)
column2: the most effective programs tackle behavioral norms through positive interactions between trained instructors and students
column3: teaching students social skills to help them refuse drugs and suggesting (as it appears
column5: that substance abuse “is not especially common and thereby attempt to counteract the misconception that abstaining from drugs makes a person an oddball.” By contrast
column6: programs that focus on raw abstinence — and especially those “led exclusively by adults
column7: with little or no involvement of students as peer leaders” like the police officers relied upon by D.A.R.E. since its inception in 1983
column8: according to Scientific American — are far less successful at deterring experimentation with dangerous substances. Worse
column9: abstinence-focused programs can backfire by narrowing in on the extreme hazards of hardcore drug use: By focusing on marijuana as a gateway drug to heroin and methamphetamines
column11: programs may “inadvertently convey the impression that alcohol and tobacco are innocuous by comparison.” Here’s an alternate theory: The kids actually want to be all right. The research into drug prevention examined by Scientific American indicates that programs focused on peer interactions are more effective
column12: suggesting that perhaps rising levels of abstinence are a generational feature
column13: on par with teens’ ridiculous vocabulary or preference for a smartphone over a person. If risky behavior was once seen as a trademark of youth
column14: today’s teens tend to be more risk-averse
column15: a portrait of “the responsible generation.” Even cringe-worthy trend stories on juice crawls and morning raves may have their social roots in a generational optimism that’s become a defining trait in contrast to the cynicism of Generation X and self-congratulatory pessimism of the Baby Boomers. " False link

column1: geekdawson 145292819248 "2016-06-02 05:21:43 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/145292819248/how-media-clearly-reflects-the-sexism-and-the "letthetruthlaugh:I wanted my first-year film students to understand what happens to a story when actual human beings inhabit your characters
column2: and the way they can inspire storytelling. And I wanted to teach them how to look at headshots and what you might be able to tell from a headshot. So for the past few years I’ve done a small experiment with them. Some troubling shit always occurs. It works like this: I bring in my giant file of head shots
column3: which include actors of all races
column7: and experience levels. Each student picks a head shot from the stack and gets a few minutes to sit with the person’s face and then make up a little story about them.  Namely
column9: they have no trouble coming up with an entire history
column15: and costume. They will often identify him without prompting as “the main character.” The only exception? “He would play the gay guy.” For white women
column16: they mostly do not come up with a job (even though it was specifically asked for)
column17: and they will identify her by her relationships. “She would play the mom/wife/love interest/best friend.” I’ve heard “She would play the slut” or “She would play the hot girl.” A lot more than once. For nonwhite men
column18: it can be equally depressing. “He’s in a buddy cop movie
column19: but he’s not the main guy
column20: he’s the partner.” “He’d play a terrorist.” “He’d play a drug dealer.” “A thug.” “A hustler.” “Homeless guy.” One Asian actor was promoted to “villain.” For nonwhite women (grab onto something sturdy
column21: like a big glass of strong liquor)
column22: sometimes they are “lucky” enough to be classified as the girlfriend/love interest/mom
column23: but I have also heard things like “Well
column24: she’d be in a romantic comedy
column26: you know?” “Maid.” “Prostitute.” “Drug addict.” I should point out that the responses are similar whether the group is all or mostly-white or extremely racially mixed
column27: and all the groups I’ve tried this with have been about equally balanced between men and women
column28: though individual responses vary. Women do a little better with women
column29: and people of color do a little better with people of color
column30: but female students sometimes forget to come up with a job for female actors and black male students sometimes tell the class that their black male actor wouldn’t be the main guy. Once the students have made their pitches
column31: we interrogate their opinions. “You seem really sure that he’s not the main character – why? What made you automatically say that?” “You said she was a mom. Was she born a mom
column32: or did she maybe do something else with her life before her magic womb opened up and gave her an identity? Who is she as a person?” In the case of the “thug“
column33: it turns out that the student was just reading off his film resume. This brilliant African American actor who regularly brings houses down doing Shakespeare on the stage and more than once made me weep at the beauty and subtlety of his performances
column34: had a list of film credits that just said “Thug #4.” “Gang member.” “Muscle.” Because that’s the film work he can get. Because it puts food on his table. So
column35: the first time I did this exercise
column36: I didn’t know that it would turn into a lesson on racism
column38: and every other kind of -ism. I thought it was just about casting. But now I know that casting is never just about casting
column39: and this day is a real teachable opportunity. Because if we do this right
column40: we get to the really awkward silence
column41: where the (now mortified) students try to sink into their chairs. Because
column43: most of them are proud Obama voters! They have been raised by feminist moms! They don’t want to be or see themselves as being racist or sexist. But their own racism and sexism is running amok in the room

column2: when in recent weeks
column3: we’ve seen a lot of LGBTQ characters
column4: female characters and people of color die on TV.  I wrote a bit about why I think this is the case
column5: and what Hollywood could do about it.     “’Anyone can die’ won’t be a truthful sentence until ‘any kind of character can be at the very heart of the story’ and ‘anyone can run a TV show’ are factual statements as well.”Nailed the issue right on the head." False link

column2: Debnam-Carey stressed that it felt definitive
column3: though she stayed mum on whether Lexa could potentially return. “When I’ve watched characters that I love and adore on TV shows and they’re sent off without a really defining moment or a clear cut reason
column11: ’” the actress said. “I’m not a fan of that type of storytelling usually. I like that it was a very passionate and then heartbreaking moment.”" False link

column1: geekdawson 141186101913 "2016-03-17 05:02:12 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/141186101913/our-creative-commons-our-stories-by-us "By the way
column2: when I reference Our Creative Commons this is what I’m talking about. (If you prefer
column4: though our social has been on a bit of a hiatus lately due to packed schedules: @wecreatecommons​)Our Creative Commons is a small business founded on the idea that more diverse voices are needed behind the scenes and in front of cameras in film and TV. This year we have focused down to producing TV for the internet (think Netflix if it only did original content) specifically intended to showcase things that include a wide range of voices and backgrounds. Everything we’re working on is in early development stages and there is a lot to do
column5: but this is my contribution (along with the team who helps me plan
column7: and create. shout out to @turnandchasethewind @shadynewjersey and @not-sorry-for-my-heart-ok
column8: you all ROCK) for a future of media that includes all of us
column9: not just straight white cis men. And a future that acknowledges
column11: and appreciates the new type of collaborative
column12: symbiotic relationship that exists between people who make the content and the audience. My personal goal is by the end of 2016 to have at least two shows up and viewable on our own custom streaming platform. There’s a lot to do to get it there
column13: but we’re going to make it happen. If you’re new here
column14: that’s what Our Creative Commons is all about and what I’m referencing when I talk about my own projects that are keeping me super busy. " True link

column1: geekdawson 141048837353 "2016-03-14 20:51:41 GMT" http://geekdawson.tumblr.com/post/141048837353/what-tv-can-learn-from-the-100-mess "clexasource: If you wanted to come up with a playbook for how to handle TV promotion and publicity in the age of social media
column2: a few of the major rules might look like this: - Don’t mislead fans or raise their hopes unrealistically.- Don’t promote your show as an ideal proponent of a certain kind of storytelling
column3: and then drop the ball in a major way with that very element of your show.- When things go south
column4: don’t pretend nothing happened.- Understand that in this day and age
column5: promotion is a two-way street: The fans that flock to your show and help raise its profile can just as easily walk away if they are disappointed or feel they’ve been manipulated. " False link
